SEARCH
Package com.oblong.jelly

Class PoolAddress

java.lang.Object
com.oblong.jelly.PoolAddress
@Immutable public final class PoolAddress extends Object
A class representing and parsing pool URIs.

The location of a pool consists of two parts: the address of its server and the pool name. One can specify the former as a PoolServerAddress object, accompanying it by the pool name as a string to create the full pool address.

As an alternative, one can also use a single string with the full pool URI and rely on PoolAddress to handle its parsing (or on any of the methods in Pool that take a single string as their pool locator).

As an example, this code snippet: 

   PoolServerAddress = new PoolServerAddress("tcp", "hostname", 2323);
   PoolAddress a = new PoolAddress(sa, "a-pool");
creates a PoolAddress that is the same as the one created as: 
   PoolAddress a = PoolAddress.fromURI("tcp://hostname:2323/a-pool");

  • Constructor Details

    • PoolAddress

      public PoolAddress(PoolServerAddress addr, String name) throws BadAddressException
      Combines a server address and a pool name to create a PoolAddress.

      name will usually be a path relative to the server address (e.g. "pname" or "rel/path/name of a pool"), and this constructor will combine the two to yield the final pool address.

      But, if name happens to be a fully qualified pool URI (e.g. "tcp://there/a-pool", addr will be ignored, and the new PoolAddress will be equal to one created using fromURI(name).

      If addr is null, a default server address (as constructed by new PoolServerAddress(null), i.e., "tcp://localhost:65456" will be used.

      Throws:
      BadAddressException - if name is not a valid pool name or URI. Note, however, that the lack of an error when constructing an address on the client side doesn't guarantee that the server will accept the pool name as a valid one.

  • Method Details

    • fromURI

      public static PoolAddress fromURI(String uri) throws BadAddressException
      Constructs a PoolAddress object from its string representation. uri must be a full pool URI, including a scheme (e.g. "tcp://"), optional hostname and port followed by a slash, and a pool name (whose validity will be checked by the pool server upon connection).
      Throws:
      BadAddressException

    • serverAddress

      public PoolServerAddress serverAddress()
      Accessor to the address of the server this pools belongs to.

    • poolName

      public String poolName()
      Accesor to the part of the address relative to the server address.

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Returns a valid URI representing this address.

      That means that it is always the case that: 

         address == PoolAddress.fromURI(address.toString());
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object

    • equals

      public boolean equals(Object o)
      Two addresses are equal if the have the same PoolServerAddress and name. In other words, the same normalized URI.
      Overrides:
      equals in class Object
